title: Research
text: My research focuses on forest entomology and disease ecology, with an emphasis on how environmental disturbance influences insect–pathogen interactions. During my Master’s research at Colorado State University, I studied Monochamus beetles as vectors of the pinewood nematode (Bursaphelenchus xylophilus) in forest systems shaped by wildfire disturbance. My work integrates field-based insect sampling, molecular screening, and statistical analysis to understand patterns of disease risk across space and time.

title: Cirriculum Vitae
text:
Education

Graduate Certificate, Data Analysis — Colorado State University 2025
Bachelor of Science, Restoration Ecology (Minor: Entomology) — Colorado State University 2022
Associate of Arts– Front Range Community College 2019

title: Cirriculum Vitae
text:
Research Experience

Student Researcher — Davis Lab of Forest Health, Entomology, Ecology & Biodiversity (CSU)
July 2021–Present
- MSc research on Monochamus beetles as vectors of the pinewood nematode (Bursaphelenchus xylophilus) in wildfire-influenced forest systems
- Field trapping across disturbance gradients; LAMP assays for nematode presence/absence; statistical modeling of spatial and temporal patterns


Research Advisor — MURALS (Multicultural Undergraduate Research and Artistry Symposium)- First Year Scholars Academy (CSU)
Sept 2025–Present
- Mentored three first-year undergraduates; designed and taught methods for a project comparing microbial communities in burned vs unburned ponderosa pine
- Field sampling (bark and needles); lab work included fungal plating, Baermann funnels, and microscopy (e.g., nematodes, tardigrades, ciliates, rotifers)


Research Intern — DAAD RISE Program (Research Internships in Science and Engineering), University of Göttingen (Germany)
Summer 2022
- Forest zoology project examining Douglas-fir introduction and impacts on arthropod diversity and functioning
- Implemented lure traps and artificial caterpillars to quantify biodiversity and predation rates in the forest canopy


Student Researcher / Field Technician — Colorado Natural Heritage Program (UCCS, Mooney Lab)
Summer 2021
- Studied ant–butterfly mutualisms in the rare hops azure butterfly (Celastrina humulus)
- Monitored ant tending interactions as a function of host plant phenology


Research Intern — U.S. Geological Survey / RECCS
Summer 2019
- Hydrology field measurements and lab-based DNA extraction to quantify biomass flux in the Powder River as a potential contaminant-tracking approach

title: Cirriculum Vitae
text:
Manuscripts in Preparation / Under Review
Nolan, H. A., Davis, T. S., & Stewart, J. Wildfire is associated with a short-term increase of pathogenic pinewood nematode (Bursaphelenchus xylophilus) in populations of sawyer beetles (Coleoptera: Cerambycidae).
Nolan, H. A., Davis, T. S., & Stewart, J. Spruce beetle kill is not associated with an increase of pathogenic pinewood nematode (Bursaphelenchus xylophilus) in populations of sawyer beetles (Coleoptera: Cerambycidae), but presence of spruce beetle kill impacts sawyer beetle size.

title: Cirriculum Vitae
text:
Technical Skills
Stats & computing: R, JMP
GIS: ArcGIS Pro
Molecular / lab: LAMP, PCR, fungal plating, Baermann funnels, DNA extraction; water/sediment processing
Field methods: insect trapping (flight interception, lure, light traps), forest measurements (BAF prism, DBH), bark punches and increment cores, pressure chamber measurements, canopy predation assays (artificial caterpillars), arthropod/plant ID; hydrology measurements

title: Hailee Amethyst Nolan
text:
LinkedIn GitHub Email
I am a forest ecologist specializing in forest entomology and disease ecology. I study the role of Monochamus beetles as vectors of pine wilt disease in forest systems shaped by wildfire disturbance. My work sits at the intersection of insect ecology, forest health, and disease dynamics, with a focus on how environmental change influences vector–pathogen interactions.
I recently completed my Master of Science at Colorado State University, where my research combines field-based beetle trapping, molecular nematode screening, and statistical modeling to evaluate how vector infection risk varies across spatial and temporal disturbance gradients. I am actively seeking PhD opportunities beginning Fall 2026 in entomology, forest ecology, or plant–insect–pathogen systems.
Outside of research, I enjoy hiking with my dog Zylah, gardening, baking, and generally spending time outdoors and traveling!
